statement:
Let $X$ be a semimartingale. Then a predictable process $\xi$ is
$X$-integrable if the stochastic integral $\int\xi\,dX$ is defined,
which is equivalent to the set
$$\left\{\int_0^t\alpha\,dX:|\alpha|\le |\xi|\textrm{ is predictable}\right\}$$
being bounded in probability, for each $t>0$. We list some properties of
$X$-integrable processes.

1.  Every locally bounded predictable process is $X$-integrable.

2.  The $X$-integrable processes are closed under linear combinations.
    That is, if $\alpha,\beta$ are $X$-integrable and
    $\lambda,\mu\in\mathbb{R}$, then $\lambda\alpha+\mu\beta$ is
    $X$-integrable.

3.  If $|\alpha|\le|\beta|$ are predictable processes and $\beta$ is
    $X$-integrable, then so is $\alpha$.

4.  A process is $X$-integrable if it is locally $X$-integrable. That
    is, if there are stopping times $\tau_n$ almost surely increasing to
    infinity and such that $1_{\{t\le\tau_n\}}\xi_t$ is $X$-integrable,
    then $\xi$ is $X$-integrable.
